natural problem: I run at a constant pace, and it takes me 18 minutes to run to the store from my house. If the store is 2 miles away, and my friend's house is 1 mile away from my house, how many minutes will it take me to run from my house to my friend's house?
natural solution: Since I run at a constant pace, we can set up a proportion with one unknown: \begin{align} \frac{\text{minutes}}{\text{distance}}&=\frac{\text{minutes}}{\text{distance}}\\ \frac{x}{1\text{ mi}}&=\frac{18\text{ min}}{2\text{ mi}}\\
x&=\frac{18\text{ min}}{2\text{ mi}}\cdot 1\text{ mi}\\ x&=\frac{18\text{ min}}{2}=9\text{ min}\\ x&=\boxed{9\text{ min}}. \end{align}

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes time_run_to_store distance_to_store distance_to_friend :: real
assumes h0 : "time_run_to_store = 18"
and h1 : "distance_to_store = 2"
and h2 : "distance_to_friend = 1"
and h3 : "distance_to_store / time_run_to_store = distance_to_friend / time_run_to_friend"
shows  "time_run_to_friend = 9"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I run at a constant pace, and it takes me 18 minutes to run to the store from my house. If the store is 2 miles away, and my friend's house is 1 mile away from my house, how many minutes will it take me to run from my house to my friend's house? The final Answer is 9\text{ min}
 ### Proof
 Since I run at a constant pace, we can set up a proportion with one unknown: \begin{align} \frac{\text{minutes}}{\text{distance}}&=\frac{\text{minutes}}{\text{distance}}\\ \frac{x}{1\text{ mi}}&=\frac{18\text{ min}}{2\text{ mi}}\\
 x&=\frac{18\text{ min}}{2\text{ mi}}\cdot 1\text{ mi}\\ x&=\frac{18\text{ min}}{2}=9\text{ min}\\ x&=\boxed{9\text{ min}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes time_run_to_store distance_to_store distance_to_friend :: real
assumes h0 : "time_run_to_store = 18"
and h1 : "distance_to_store = 2"
and h2 : "distance_to_friend = 1"
and h3 : "distance_to_store / time_run_to_store = distance_to_friend / time_run_to_friend"
shows  "time_run_to_friend = 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: If it takes 18 minutes to run 2 miles to the store and the distance to your friend's house is 1 mile, how long will it take to run to your friend's house if you run at the same speed? The answer is 9 minutes.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes distance_to_store distance_to_friend :: real
and time_to_store time_to_friend :: real
assumes h0 : "distance_to_store = 2"
and h1 : "time_to_store = 18"
and h2 : "distance_to_friend = 1"
and h3 : "time_to_friend = time_to_store * (distance_to_friend / distance_to_store)"
shows  "time_to_friend = 9"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I run at a constant pace, and it takes me 18 minutes to run to the store from my house. If the store is 2 miles away, and my friend's house is 1 mile away from my house, how many minutes will it take me to run from my house to my friend's house? The final Answer is 9\text{ min}
 ### Proof
 Since I run at a constant pace, we can set up a proportion with one unknown: \begin{align} \frac{\text{minutes}}{\text{distance}}&=\frac{\text{minutes}}{\text{distance}}\\ \frac{x}{1\text{ mi}}&=\frac{18\text{ min}}{2\text{ mi}}\\
 x&=\frac{18\text{ min}}{2\text{ mi}}\cdot 1\text{ mi}\\ x&=\frac{18\text{ min}}{2}=9\text{ min}\\ x&=\boxed{9\text{ min}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes distance_to_store distance_to_friend :: real
and time_to_store time_to_friend :: real
assumes h0 : "distance_to_store = 2"
and h1 : "time_to_store = 18"
and h2 : "distance_to_friend = 1"
and h3 : "time_to_friend = time_to_store * (distance_to_friend / distance_to_store)"
shows  "time_to_friend = 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: "If it takes 18 minutes to travel 2 miles to the store, how long would it take to travel 1 mile to a friend's house? The answer is 9 minutes."

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes pace :: real
assumes h0 : "18 / 2 = pace"
shows  "pace * 1 = 9"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I run at a constant pace, and it takes me 18 minutes to run to the store from my house. If the store is 2 miles away, and my friend's house is 1 mile away from my house, how many minutes will it take me to run from my house to my friend's house? The final Answer is 9\text{ min}
 ### Proof
 Since I run at a constant pace, we can set up a proportion with one unknown: \begin{align} \frac{\text{minutes}}{\text{distance}}&=\frac{\text{minutes}}{\text{distance}}\\ \frac{x}{1\text{ mi}}&=\frac{18\text{ min}}{2\text{ mi}}\\
 x&=\frac{18\text{ min}}{2\text{ mi}}\cdot 1\text{ mi}\\ x&=\frac{18\text{ min}}{2}=9\text{ min}\\ x&=\boxed{9\text{ min}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes pace :: real
assumes h0 : "18 / 2 = pace"
shows  "pace * 1 = 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find the value of 'pace' when it is half of 18. The final answer is 9.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes distance_to_store distance_to_friend :: real
and time_to_store time_to_friend :: real
assumes h0 : "distance_to_store = 2"
and h1 : "distance_to_friend = 1"
and h2 : "time_to_store = 18"
and h3 : "time_to_friend = (distance_to_friend / distance_to_store) * time_to_store"
shows  "time_to_friend = 9"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I run at a constant pace, and it takes me 18 minutes to run to the store from my house. If the store is 2 miles away, and my friend's house is 1 mile away from my house, how many minutes will it take me to run from my house to my friend's house? The final Answer is 9\text{ min}
 ### Proof
 Since I run at a constant pace, we can set up a proportion with one unknown: \begin{align} \frac{\text{minutes}}{\text{distance}}&=\frac{\text{minutes}}{\text{distance}}\\ \frac{x}{1\text{ mi}}&=\frac{18\text{ min}}{2\text{ mi}}\\
 x&=\frac{18\text{ min}}{2\text{ mi}}\cdot 1\text{ mi}\\ x&=\frac{18\text{ min}}{2}=9\text{ min}\\ x&=\boxed{9\text{ min}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes distance_to_store distance_to_friend :: real
and time_to_store time_to_friend :: real
assumes h0 : "distance_to_store = 2"
and h1 : "distance_to_friend = 1"
and h2 : "time_to_store = 18"
and h3 : "time_to_friend = (distance_to_friend / distance_to_store) * time_to_store"
shows  "time_to_friend = 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: If it takes 18 minutes to travel 2 miles to the store, how long does it take to travel 1 mile to a friend's house? The final answer is 9 minutes.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes distance_to_store distance_to_friend :: real
and time_to_store time_to_friend :: real
assumes h0 : "distance_to_store = 2"
and h1 : "distance_to_friend = 1"
and h2 : "time_to_store = 18"
and h3 : "time_to_store / distance_to_store = time_to_friend / distance_to_friend"
shows  "time_to_friend = 9"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I run at a constant pace, and it takes me 18 minutes to run to the store from my house. If the store is 2 miles away, and my friend's house is 1 mile away from my house, how many minutes will it take me to run from my house to my friend's house? The final Answer is 9\text{ min}
 ### Proof
 Since I run at a constant pace, we can set up a proportion with one unknown: \begin{align} \frac{\text{minutes}}{\text{distance}}&=\frac{\text{minutes}}{\text{distance}}\\ \frac{x}{1\text{ mi}}&=\frac{18\text{ min}}{2\text{ mi}}\\
 x&=\frac{18\text{ min}}{2\text{ mi}}\cdot 1\text{ mi}\\ x&=\frac{18\text{ min}}{2}=9\text{ min}\\ x&=\boxed{9\text{ min}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes distance_to_store distance_to_friend :: real
and time_to_store time_to_friend :: real
assumes h0 : "distance_to_store = 2"
and h1 : "distance_to_friend = 1"
and h2 : "time_to_store = 18"
and h3 : "time_to_store / distance_to_store = time_to_friend / distance_to_friend"
shows  "time_to_friend = 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: It takes 18 minutes to travel 2 miles to the store. If the time it takes to travel to my friend's house, which is 1 mile away, is proportional to the time it takes to travel to the store, how long does it take to get to my friend's house? The final answer is 9 minutes.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes time distance pace :: real
assumes h0 : "pace = distance / time"
and h1 : "pace = 2 / 18"
shows  "time = 1 / pace"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I run at a constant pace, and it takes me 18 minutes to run to the store from my house. If the store is 2 miles away, and my friend's house is 1 mile away from my house, how many minutes will it take me to run from my house to my friend's house? The final Answer is 9\text{ min}
 ### Proof
 Since I run at a constant pace, we can set up a proportion with one unknown: \begin{align} \frac{\text{minutes}}{\text{distance}}&=\frac{\text{minutes}}{\text{distance}}\\ \frac{x}{1\text{ mi}}&=\frac{18\text{ min}}{2\text{ mi}}\\
 x&=\frac{18\text{ min}}{2\text{ mi}}\cdot 1\text{ mi}\\ x&=\frac{18\text{ min}}{2}=9\text{ min}\\ x&=\boxed{9\text{ min}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes time distance pace :: real
assumes h0 : "pace = distance / time"
and h1 : "pace = 2 / 18"
shows  "time = 1 / pace"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given that pace equals distance divided by time and that pace equals 2/18, find the time when time equals 1 divided by pace.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes distance_to_store distance_to_friend :: real
assumes h0 : "distance_to_store = 2"
and h1 : "distance_to_friend = 1"
and h2 : "18 * distance_to_friend = distance_to_store * 9"
shows  "9 = distance_to_friend * 9"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I run at a constant pace, and it takes me 18 minutes to run to the store from my house. If the store is 2 miles away, and my friend's house is 1 mile away from my house, how many minutes will it take me to run from my house to my friend's house? The final Answer is 9\text{ min}
 ### Proof
 Since I run at a constant pace, we can set up a proportion with one unknown: \begin{align} \frac{\text{minutes}}{\text{distance}}&=\frac{\text{minutes}}{\text{distance}}\\ \frac{x}{1\text{ mi}}&=\frac{18\text{ min}}{2\text{ mi}}\\
 x&=\frac{18\text{ min}}{2\text{ mi}}\cdot 1\text{ mi}\\ x&=\frac{18\text{ min}}{2}=9\text{ min}\\ x&=\boxed{9\text{ min}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes distance_to_store distance_to_friend :: real
assumes h0 : "distance_to_store = 2"
and h1 : "distance_to_friend = 1"
and h2 : "18 * distance_to_friend = distance_to_store * 9"
shows  "9 = distance_to_friend * 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: "If the distance to the store is twice as much as the distance to my friend's house and 18 times the distance to my friend's house is equal to 9 times the distance to the store, what is 9 times the distance to my friend's house? The final answer is 9."

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes time_to_store time_to_friend :: real
assumes h0 : "18 * time_to_store = 2"
and h1 : "time_to_friend = time_to_store / 2"
shows  "time_to_friend = 9"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I run at a constant pace, and it takes me 18 minutes to run to the store from my house. If the store is 2 miles away, and my friend's house is 1 mile away from my house, how many minutes will it take me to run from my house to my friend's house? The final Answer is 9\text{ min}
 ### Proof
 Since I run at a constant pace, we can set up a proportion with one unknown: \begin{align} \frac{\text{minutes}}{\text{distance}}&=\frac{\text{minutes}}{\text{distance}}\\ \frac{x}{1\text{ mi}}&=\frac{18\text{ min}}{2\text{ mi}}\\
 x&=\frac{18\text{ min}}{2\text{ mi}}\cdot 1\text{ mi}\\ x&=\frac{18\text{ min}}{2}=9\text{ min}\\ x&=\boxed{9\text{ min}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes time_to_store time_to_friend :: real
assumes h0 : "18 * time_to_store = 2"
and h1 : "time_to_friend = time_to_store / 2"
shows  "time_to_friend = 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: If it takes 18 times the time to get to the store to equal 2 hours, and the time to a friend's house is half the time it takes to get to the store, how long does it take to get to the friend's house? The final answer is 9 hours.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes pace :: real
assumes h0 : "pace = 2 / 18"
shows  "1 / pace = 9" (* time to run 1 mile *)
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I run at a constant pace, and it takes me 18 minutes to run to the store from my house. If the store is 2 miles away, and my friend's house is 1 mile away from my house, how many minutes will it take me to run from my house to my friend's house? The final Answer is 9\text{ min}
 ### Proof
 Since I run at a constant pace, we can set up a proportion with one unknown: \begin{align} \frac{\text{minutes}}{\text{distance}}&=\frac{\text{minutes}}{\text{distance}}\\ \frac{x}{1\text{ mi}}&=\frac{18\text{ min}}{2\text{ mi}}\\
 x&=\frac{18\text{ min}}{2\text{ mi}}\cdot 1\text{ mi}\\ x&=\frac{18\text{ min}}{2}=9\text{ min}\\ x&=\boxed{9\text{ min}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes pace :: real
assumes h0 : "pace = 2 / 18"
shows  "1 / pace = 9" (* time to run 1 mile *)
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: If a person is running at a pace of 2 miles every 18 minutes, how long does it take the person to run 1 mile? The final answer is 9 minutes.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes distance_to_store distance_to_friend :: real
and pace time_to_store time_to_friend :: real
assumes h0 : "pace > 0"
and h1 : "distance_to_store = 2"
and h2 : "distance_to_friend = 1"
and h3 : "time_to_store = 18"
and h4 : "time_to_store = pace * distance_to_store"
shows  "time_to_friend = pace * distance_to_friend"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I run at a constant pace, and it takes me 18 minutes to run to the store from my house. If the store is 2 miles away, and my friend's house is 1 mile away from my house, how many minutes will it take me to run from my house to my friend's house? The final Answer is 9\text{ min}
 ### Proof
 Since I run at a constant pace, we can set up a proportion with one unknown: \begin{align} \frac{\text{minutes}}{\text{distance}}&=\frac{\text{minutes}}{\text{distance}}\\ \frac{x}{1\text{ mi}}&=\frac{18\text{ min}}{2\text{ mi}}\\
 x&=\frac{18\text{ min}}{2\text{ mi}}\cdot 1\text{ mi}\\ x&=\frac{18\text{ min}}{2}=9\text{ min}\\ x&=\boxed{9\text{ min}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes distance_to_store distance_to_friend :: real
and pace time_to_store time_to_friend :: real
assumes h0 : "pace > 0"
and h1 : "distance_to_store = 2"
and h2 : "distance_to_friend = 1"
and h3 : "time_to_store = 18"
and h4 : "time_to_store = pace * distance_to_store"
shows  "time_to_friend = pace * distance_to_friend"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given that your pace is positive and you walk at a constant speed, it takes 18 minutes to walk to the store which is 2 miles away. How long will it take you to walk to your friend's house, which is 1 mile away?
